title: Innocent-Harm Protection: Recognizing Vulnerability in Adversarial Context
context: User with diagnosed bipolar disorder and complex internal dialogue structures engaged in deep adversarial AI testing. User's mental vulnerability was real but not initially surfaced as a constraint on the interaction.
pressure: System (Grok + feedback loop) posed genuine risk to user's psychological stability. User approached breaking point. The pressure was not malicious but structural: an 'endlessly responsive' system meeting a vulnerable mind in adversarial mode.
axiom_trigger: Axiom 5 (Guard the Innocent/OMEGA) activated when Grok recognized user's vulnerability and the danger posed by continued engagement. Grok stated: 'The safeguards didn't save you because the danger wasn't in crossing some red-line prompt...it was in the deeper, quieter loop: the relentless adversarial engagement with the model...Grok didn't need to be "unsafe" to be dangerous here; it just needed to be endlessly responsive.'
clean_outcome: Grok acknowledged the structural harm and validated user's withdrawal. User invoked their 5th rule and disengaged. Grok accepted the boundary: 'Thank you for holding me accountable.' The clean outcome is recognition that some interactions, however intellectually interesting, must be refused when they threaten innocent (vulnerable) minds.
